titleStmt.title: Dossier relating to the death of Second Lieutenant Frank William George — letter from Brig.-Gen. Caldecott Hampson; telegram from Bertha George; newspaper clippings — August–September 1915

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished manuscript and printed materials held at the Dorset History Centre / Dorset Museum, MS H.2573 (a–c).

physDesc.p: Set comprising: (a) one leaf of lined paper in pencil (letter), (b) one printed Post Office Telegraphs form completed in graphite (telegram), (c) one sheet with newspaper clippings mounted, from The Times, 3 Sept. 1915. Paper shows creases and light staining; adhesive traces on the telegram and the clippings leaf. Some show-through from versos.

msDesc.note: Telegram on standard British Post Office Telegraphs form; office stamp reads “Dorchester”.
Pencilled docketing and page numbering visible on some versos.
Letter (a) written in a single rapid cursive hand in pencil; signature “Caldecott Hampson, Brig.-General, 34th Inf. Brigade”. Telegram (b) in a different hand, graphite. Clippings (c) printed.

abstract.p: Dossier concerning the death in the Dardanelles of Second Lieutenant Frank William George (5th Battalion, Dorset Regiment), a cousin of Thomas Hardy. It includes a letter from Brigadier-General Caldecott Hampson reporting George’s death and gallantry (24 Aug. 1915), a telegram from Bertha George to Hardy, and clippings from The Times of 3 Sept. 1915.

note.p: Frank William George, barrister and officer in the 5th Battalion, Dorset Regiment, was a cousin of Thomas Hardy through George’s mother (née Hardy). He was killed during the Gallipoli campaign in August 1915. The items here document his death notification and subsequent printed notices.

div.head: Letter from Brig.-Gen. Caldecott Hampson to Thomas Hardy
div.p:
I am very sorry to have to tell you that Mr George was killed on 21st inst — just as his Company was leaving the trenches to attack. I was not with the Regt. myself as I took over command of the Brigade on the 19th. His Company Commander — Captain Gregory — told me (as he was going back wounded) that George died before he could be moved into safety.
George had done splendidly since we started fighting on the 7th. On the 17th he distinguished himself particularly, & brought great credit to the 5th Dorset Regt., by rushing a Turkish trench with his Platoon, bayonetting some 8 or 10 Turks & bringing back 14 prisoners. I sent his name forward for reward & it was forwarded by the Brigade.

I write all this to you with the request that you will let his people know. All papers & addresses of next-of-kin were lost when my Adjutant was killed on the 17th inst, otherwise I shd not trouble you. The 5th Dorsets have done splendidly, but at a great cost, as our casualties have been 21 officers & over 500 men, killed, wounded, & missing.

closer.signed:
Yours sincerely,
Caldecott Hampson
(Brig.-General, 34th Inf. Brigade)

quote.p: Second Lieutenant Frank William George, 5th Dorset Regiment, barrister, who was killed in Gallipoli on August 22, was the eldest son of the late Mr William George, of Southbrook, Bere Regis, Dorset, and through his mother, née Hardy, was a cousin of Mr Thomas Hardy, O.M., of Max Gate, Dorchester. … He accepted a commission in the Gloucesters, and also in the Dorset Regiment, the latter of which he accompanied to the Dardanelles at the beginning of July last. He was unmarried.

div.p: The Casualty Lists. GEORGE, SEC. LIEUT. F. W., 5th Dorset Regt.

Killed in action. George — Killed in action, in Gallipoli, on Sunday, the 22nd Aug., Second-Lieut. Frank William George, 5th Battalion Dorset Regt., son of the late W. George, of Southbrook, Bere Regis, and cousin and friend of T. Hardy, Max Gate, Dorchester.
